content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a condensed summary of the section title and findings. The Act may be cited as the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997". Congress finds that tuition at 4-year public colleges increased significantly from 1980-1995, while household income and consumer goods costs also rose. A 1995 survey showed high concern about college affordability among freshmen. College affordability is at its highest in the last 30 years, making paying for a college education one of the costliest investments for American families. Establishment of National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education, known as the "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education," with defined membership. The National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education is composed of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education, each with expertise. The National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education consists of 7 members with expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, and higher education administration. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with the Vice Chairperson assuming duties in the absence of the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions. Appointments under the National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. If an appointment is not made within this timeframe, the Chairman or Ranking Minority Member of the Committee on Education and the Workforce may act on behalf of the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Education and the Workforce committee can act on behalf of specific leaders in the House and Senate. Each member of the Commission has one equal vote. Vacancies on the Commission do not affect its operations. The Commission operates with equal votes for each member. Vacancies do not impact its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive additional pay but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The initial meeting of the Commission is required. The Commission operates with equal votes for each member and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The initial meeting of the Commission must occur within 40 days after the enactment of this Act. The Commission operates with equal votes for each member and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The initial meeting of the Commission must occur within 40 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study and make recommendations on tuition increases, methods to reduce tuition, administrative costs in colleges and universities, and faculty workload and remuneration. The Commission will study trends in faculty workload, faculty-to-student ratios, classroom hours, tenure practices, construction of academic facilities, modernization for new technologies, and the impact of financial aid on tuition increases. The Commission will study the impact of tuition discounting on tuition increases, demographics of aid recipients, use of Federal financial aid to offset increases, and the influence of laws on tuition. Recommendations will be made to reduce mandates and establish a mechanism for timely action. The Commission will establish a mechanism for distributing data on tuition trends and costs, assess the impact of student financial aid on tuition increases, and address other relevant topics. They will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 120 days of their first meeting. The Commission will submit a detailed report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote from Commission members present. SEC. 5. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from Federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission can request information from Federal agencies under the Act, and agencies must provide information to the Commission upon request by the Chairperson. The Commission can request facilities, services, and personnel from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties under the Act. Additionally, the Commission is authorized to use the United States mails and enter into contracts as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can enter into contracts for research purposes and the Chairperson has the power to appoint staff as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and staff at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Expenses of the Commission are authorized to be appropriated not to exceed $650,000 and remain available until expended or one year after termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report.
